Culture Trips     Rail Trips     Private Trips     Offers     Guides         Guides                  £   CHOOSE CURRENCY    US$ US Dollar     € Euro     £ British Pound     AU$ Australian Dollar     CA$ Canadian Dollar     NZ$ New Zealand Dollar               How to Spend 48 Hours in Minca      Minca | © Mark Rowland / Flickr          Chris Bell  16 December 2019        Copy Link Facebook Email Twitter Pinterest           Minca is a lovely little mountain village in the foothills of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta mountains on the Caribbean coast of Colombia. It’s highly popular with travelers due to its relaxed atmosphere, beautiful landscapes and excellent hostels. However, many visitors don’t have weeks to enjoy chilling out in the village, so here’s a quick guide on how to make the most of 48 hours in Minca.          View All Trips                    Arriving at lunchtime from Santa Marta, the first thing to do is grab a bite to eat in town, and there’s nowhere better to do that than at The Lazy Cat, a great little restaurant just opposite the village church, which overlooks the river and serves the best burgers and burritos in town. Then wander across the bridge towards Cafe Minca for a local coffee. Even if you’re not staying there, the adjacent Hotel Minca is worth a visit to enjoy their amazing hummingbird feeders, which attract an array of the colorful little birds.          Take a spin to find your perfect small-group trip destination Passports ready? Your next destination is... View Trip Spin      India   Mexico   Greece   Egypt   South Africa   Croatia   Iceland   Bali   Japan   Ecuador   Morocco   Spain   Turkey   Thailand          Lovely hummingbird at Hotel Minca | © Chris Bell / The Culture Trip                It’s then time to head for your hostel. The best place in town to stay is the delightful Casa Loma Hostel, which is perched on a hillside above the village and commands amazing views over the distant Caribbean Sea and the gorgeous green mountains. Check in here, order a delicious vegan dinner for the evening, then spend the rest of your first day relaxing, enjoying the view and waiting for the sunset. Casa Loma has the best sunset views in town, and there’s even a great happy hour to make the evening pass even quicker. Get an early night, because there’s a lot to do tomorrow.     Wake up nice and early (it’s much cooler and fresher in the morning), and head down into Minca to grab a mototaxi up into the mountains to La Victoria Coffee Farm. This working coffee farm is one of the oldest in Colombia and offers a fascinating glimpse at the old machinery once used to harvest the magic little beans, which is still in use today! Take the tour at La Victoria in the morning, then stick around for lunch to enjoy one of their delicious sandwiches and an ice cold Happy Toucan Beer, which is also brewed on site. After lunch, walk back towards Minca from the farm along the road towards Pozos Naturales (grab another mototaxi if you’re not the hiking type).       Coffee drying at La Victoria in Minca | © Chris Bell / The Culture Trip                Pozos Naturales is a lovely little swimming hole on the river between La Victoria and Minca, and is the perfect place to enjoy a refreshing dip in the cooling waters of the Sierra Nevada (don’t forget to pack your bathing suit when you leave in the morning). There are many stalls along the road from the Pozos to Minca, where you can sample local chocolate and honey products, and enjoy the mountain views. Always keep an eye out for Toucans as well: they are commonly seen along this road. Grab some dinner in Minca – you’re forgiven if you choose The Lazy Cat again – and head back up to Casa Loma: there’s still the happy hour to look forward to!     On your final morning, rise nice and early and meet up with Jungle Joe down in the village – he offers excellent beginner’s birding tours on the trails around the village and is the perfect man with whom to discover the feathered joys of the Santa Marta Mountains. You can see toucans, parrots, owls, woodpeckers and much more with Joe, and he’s a patient and understandable guide. You’ll be finished by 9:30 am, which gives you a couple more hours to enjoy: hop on a quick mototaxi and head to Marinka Waterfalls to enjoy a last cooling dip in the river, before you head back down the mountains to the sweltering heat of the coast.       A beautiful waterfall near Minca |  © Niek van Son/Flickr | © Niek van Son / Flickr                 So there you have it: 48 amazing hours in Minca. Coffee farms, birding, waterfall swimming, great food and even some booze thrown in too. You really couldn’t pack more into your two days in Minca if you tried! Unauthorized use is prohibited.TravelTravelerSip Your Way Through Colombia’s Coffee TownsA new coffee destination bears fruit in the country’s north.ByBill FinkPhotographs byFrancesco LastrucciPublished July 19, 2016• 8 min readShareTweetEmailSomething is brewing in the small Colombian town of Minca. It smells of caramel, bark, charcoal, and chocolate. The source? Coffee beans, fresh from backyard roasters, their sharp burnt odor cutting through the humid tropical haze.Here in northern Colombia, the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta range rises straight from the shores of the Caribbean. Long left undeveloped due to political troubles, this now peaceful area draws urban Colombians and savvy international visitors to the palm-fringed beaches of Tayrona National Park, the ancient archaeological site of Ciudad Perdida, and the birding paradise of the jungles around Minca.Recently, Minca and the Sierra Nevada have begun to attract coffee-loving travelers, a collection of connoisseurs and curious backpackers eager to discover what Juan Pablo Campos, general manager of the Lohas Beans trade group, calls “the most important Colombian region for organic coffee.”Using a pestle, Minca coffee grower Angel Maria Orozco peels the hard outer skin of dried coffee beans.Photograph by Francesco LastrucciPlease be respectful of copyright. Unauthorized use is prohibited.While coffee is not native to Colombia, the plant has flourished for centuries on the country’s steep, shade-covered mountains, with rainfall, altitude, and temperatures ideal for growing the mellow, medium-bodied arabica-style bean. Colombia has been exporting coffee since the early 1800s, and in 2015 alone shipped 840,000 tons of coffee beans. Represented by the fictional ambassadors Juan Valdez and his trusty burro, Conchita, “Café de Colombia” has become known worldwide.A map of northern Colombia, where the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta range rises straight from the shores of the Caribbean
NG Maps, World Database on Protected AreasPlease be respectful of copyright. Unauthorized use is prohibited.Colombia’s better-known “coffee triangle” in the country’s southwest now supports a well-trod tourist track between luxury lodges and standardized plantation tours, but the Sierra Nevada still offers an authentic journey into the past—and a taste of the future of Colombian coffee. In remote highlands, indigenous tribes of Kogi and Arhuaco lead the way in organic coffee production, developing a sustainable farming network that combines traditional spiritual beliefs with modern planting knowledge. These farms embrace generations-old techniques and tools to produce sought-after organic blends, with many beans “triple certified” as organic, fair trade, and rain forest-friendly.A local harvest of organically grown coffee fruit eventually ends up as a drink to linger over at Ikaro Café, in Santa Marta.Photograph by Francesco LastrucciPlease be respectful of copyright. Unauthorized use is prohibited.The gateway to the region is the sunny Caribbean seaside city of Santa Marta, where the bitter street blend of tinto (from the Spanish word for ink) black coffee is sweetened with spoonfuls of sugar. Coffee aficionados will skip the tinto, as well as the ubiquitous Juan Valdez chain stores, and head to Santa Marta’s smaller shops, such as Ikaro Café.Exploring the area’s coffee culture is best done during harvest season, from about November through February, and can be as simple as hiring a taxi for the approximately 40-minute, 15-mile bumpy ride from the sea to the hills. Visits to tribal lands require special permission or an organized trip from an approved local operator such as Wiwa Tour.A stop at Hacienda la Victoria above Minca is like traveling to 1892, when the farm was founded. Husband-and-wife owners Micky and Claudia Weber provide a bean-to-brew education on growing, processing, and roasting coffee. Visitors will see the same well-oiled machinery in use since the farm’s beginnings: water-powered generators, gravity-driven sorters, and hand-cranked presses. Tours conclude with a tasting of their blends, often accompanied by homemade apple pie. Other local farms promote scheduled and drop-in tours and tastings of high-end coffees—a difference from only a few years ago when Colombia had an unofficial policy of “export the best, and drink the rest.”At Hacienda la Victoria, owner Claudia Weber inhales the robust aroma of freshly washed and dried coffee beans.Photograph by Francesco LastrucciPlease be respectful of copyright. Unauthorized use is prohibited.Drinking a good cup of coffee is just the beginning of a trip to Minca, where swaths of coffee beans dry on streetside tarps in season. Hiking trails wind through Sierra Nevada rain forest to the Marinka and Pozo Azul waterfalls. Hundreds of butterfly and bird species native to the area include “parrots so plentiful they’re like pigeons,” according to one visitor.A local harvest of organically grown coffee fruit in northern Colombia
Photograph by Francesco LastrucciPlease be respectful of copyright. Unauthorized use is prohibited.Minca plantations may flash back a few generations, but indigenous Kogi farms (or those of the more remote Arhuaco), located deeper in the mountains, are a journey back centuries. The tribes live without electricity in traditional adobe huts with thatched roofs. They often carry their mochila (handwoven knapsack) and wear homespun cotton clothing, white to symbolize the purity of nature. Their traditional conical headgear represents sacred snowcapped mountain peaks. Their mamos (spiritual guides) perform purification ceremonies of prayer and song prior to planting and harvesting the beans.It all works in harmony with the land, their neighbors, and modern markets, nurturing a future model not only for growing coffee but for ripening Colombian tourism itself.Where to Get a Cup of JoeIkaro Café Local organic coffee, vegan and vegetarian fare, and a bright interior make this one of the best hangouts in Santa Marta.Tienda Café Fans of this classic Minca spot savor their cups of local roasts (and a brownie) outside on the porch, but head inside for a trove of handicrafts for sale.Hacienda la Victoria Enjoy un café  at its source at  this 124-year-old family-owned coffee plantation, which also offers tours and an on-site bistro.Nat Geo ExpeditionsBook your next trip with Peace of MindSearch TripsWhere to StayEcohabs Tayrona Thatched seaside bungalows designed by a local architect nestle in Tayrona National Park.La Brisa Loca At this social Santa Marta hostel, friendships form at the courtyard pool and the rooftop bar.Casa Loma Minca The view from the top is worth the climb up the long flight of stairs to this Minca hostel on a hill.Travel to Colombia with Nat Geo A 12-day itinerary includes the country’s southeastern coffee triangle and Tayrona National Park.BILL FINK (@finktravels) can often be found with a fresh cup of Colombia Luminosa in Oakland, California. Visiting Minca, Colombia



FoodTravelDrink



Apr 6

Written By 






On my recent trip to Colombia with my sister, we spent a couple nights in Minca, which is in the mountains a few hours north of Cartagena. It’s a small town with plenty to do!Scroll down to see a map of all mentioned places.EatDuni























Duni is a cafe serving a full breakfast and lunch menu, as well as homemade breads and ice cream, in a beautiful space. Get here early for your pick of their homemade breads, and definitely enjoy a meal if you have time. Everything was fresh, delicious, and thoughtfully presented. If you’re feeling decadent, go for their chocolate bread french toast. The staff is lean and service can be a little slow, so it’s definitely a place to sit and relax. La Miga













Another cafe with delicious breads and coffees. The chocolate bread at La Miga, which is very different from Duni’s version, was so good. We saw some people ordering sandwiches, but breads and coffee seem to be their main thing. When we were there, they were offering generous samples at the counter. On Google Maps this is called “Crumb Bakery.”Sailor Will























Sailor Will was on our way to our hostel, so we stopped in for lunch right after we got off the colectivo from Santa Marta. The space was beautiful, the staff was really friendly, and we could see the small kitchen from our table. We shared the menu del dia, which was a big portion of rice, meat, plantains, avocado, and beans. We didn't get pictures of the food, but obviously plenty of pictures of the Club Colombias we washed our meal down with.El Bistro de la Victoria























El Bistro de la Victoria is the restaurant attached to Finca Victoria (more on that below). After a very steep hike up to the coffee farm, we were so happy to sit down at the Bistro with a couple of cold beers and sandwiches before our coffee tour. The sandwiches were huge and we probably could have shared one. Nevada Cerveceria























The beers we drank at El Bistro de la Victoria are from Nevada Cerveceria, the brewery right next door to the coffee farm. You can only find their beers in a few places in this region, so I recommend trying them if you come across them. We had the pilsner and really liked it, and if you’re judging a book by its cover, the labels are pretty cool. Casa Loma

 









 

Casa Loma, the hostel we stayed at served homemade vegetarian breakfast, lunch, and dinner at reasonable prices. We ate dinner there both nights of our stay, and some people who weren’t even staying at the hostel came for the meal (it’s about a 10-minute hike uphill from town, which should say something!). Each night there’s one appetizer, entree, and dessert on the menu, which is posted on a chalkboard that morning so you can decide if you want to sign up. The food is individually plated and served at the shared tables where you can get to know your fellow travelers. Both our dinners were delicious with generous portions and high-quality ingredients. Lazy CatWe didn’t get to try Lazy Cat, right across from Sailor Inn, but we heard from multiple people that while eating on the outdoor deck, a Toucan stopped by, ate some fries, and flew away. Sounds worth it just for that!DoSunset























The sunsets in Minca are beautiful. Get up to any high point and watch the sun go down and the sky change colors in between the mountains. We watched the sunset from the sunset deck at our hostel both nights. Like the dinners, many people come up to Casa Loma just for that. Pozo Azul























It’s about a 45-minute hike up the road from town before a 15-minute walk down the path to Pozo Azul, a swimming hole. The first swimming hole was packed. We crossed this area (you have to walk through the water, so we had to take our socks and sneakers off and then put them back on) and hiked up to the second swimming hole, which was less crowded and a bit deeper. We watched teenage boys jump off the high cliff before we jumped off a slightly lower cliff :). We hiked just a little bit farther up to another swimming hole that was virtually empty, where we sat and read for a bit. There are no amenities here, save for a couple ladies grilling plantains at the entrance, so come prepared. Finca Victoria























We debated hiking up to Finca Victoria from Pozo Azul or taking a moto-taxi but ultimately walked up and took a moto-taxi back down. This hike up is very steep and challenging, but with beautiful views. We speed-walked (as much as we could uphill) and it took us 50 minutes from the start of the path to Pozo Azul. We started with lunch at the restaurant attached to the farm (see above) before our tour. There’s no tour schedule, they just take you around whenever you’re ready, maybe waiting to see if a couple more people show up. The tour costs $15,000 pesos and includes a cup of their coffee. La Victoria has been around since 1892 and uses water and gravity to power their automatic production of coffee beans. It’s pretty impressive and we learned a lot from our knowledgeable tour guide.Chill























Especially if you’re coming to Minca from a big city, this is a good time to relax. Life seems pretty laid-back here, and our hostel was a great place to catch up on reading, play cards, and take in the views while surrounded by nature.Moto-taxiAs mentioned, we took a moto-taxi back to our hostel from Finca Victoria. Look for the guys in black polos with blue writing; these are the official Minca moto-taxi drivers. It’s a fun experience, just hold on tight!  We were only in Minca for two nights so didn’t get to do everything. Here are a few other activities we read about on the blog Practical Wanderlust: Las PiedrasLas Cascadas de MarinkaFinca La CandelariaShoppingStayCasa Loma Minca























We were really happy with our decision to stay at Casa Loma. As I mentioned a couple times above, people who aren’t even sleeping there come up for meals and the sunset because they have so much to offer. They have a number of different types of accommodations including private rooms, open-air huts, dorms, hammocks, and tents. We chose the Casa Luna hut for its views and its private bathroom (the only one offered). This hut is secluded from the rest of the camp and has a wide open view of the mountains, plus the night sky full of stars - something you don’t get in New York City! The shower has the same view, which was pretty amazing. The hut has a mosquito net over the bed and a big wooden locker, which we put all our stuff in when not using, including toiletries, for security and to keep animals away. The hut has a curtain in lieu of a door, and the noises we heard in the night took some getting used to, but waking up and going to bed with that view was worth it. Even though we stayed in the secluded hut with our own bathroom, we took advantage of the benefits of staying in a hostel, such as group dinners and meeting other travelers. We enjoyed sitting in the hammocks and at the picnic tables in the main lodge playing cards and reading. If you can manage the hike up to Casa Loma from town, I recommend booking a room here!EAT AND DO IN MINCA - MAP VIEW

14 EPIC Things to Do in Minca, Colombia



FollowFollowFollow







During the 9 weeks I travelled in Colombia, I visited a lot of mountain villages. But Minca was by far my favourite. Its prime location among the Sierra Nevada’s verdant mountaintops, the abundance of magical waterfalls and its endearing village charm stopped me in my tracks, and for a few more days than I had planned. There are so many exciting things to do in Minca, Colombia, you might end up extending your stay here too!
Just a few years ago, this Colombian village was considered off the beaten path. Now it’s on the radar. But it’s still no gringolandia. It has retained its small-town allure, and the addition of a few new hipster cafes, restaurants and hostels make anyone’s experience in Minca, Colombia, all the more magical. Plus, visiting Minca also means you get to say you visited the highest coastal range in the world, because the Sierra Nevada is, well, just that!
In this post, we’ll dive into everything from what to do in Minca, how long you should stay, how to get to Minca, and where to eat in Minca. Get your travel planner out and ready!

How long should I stay in Minca?
While most people only choose to spend about 2 days in Minca, there are plenty of things to do in this sleepy mountain town to keep you fully occupied for a week.
However long you choose to stay here, use this list of the best things to do in Minca, Colombia, to help you plan your visit.






Minca’s main street




How to get to Minca, Colombia?
If you’re wondering how to get to Minca, Colombia, you’ll be glad to know it’s not that difficult.
The cheapest way to get there is to hop on a bus from Santa Marta. Buses leave from the main square and will set you back 9’000 COP per person. It’s a short 1-hour journey, but you do have to wait for the bus to fill up before it leaves. The last bus also leaves at 5 pm.
Also bear in mind the location of where you’re staying. If it’s not in the village, you’ll have to pay extra for a motorbike to take you there.
The other option is to get a taxi. This is the best option if there are a few of you or if you’ve missed the last bus. The going rate is about 60’000 COP, but you can easily get it for 50’000 COP. It’s always worth negotiating!

14 Things to do in Minca, Colombia
Visit the Marinka Waterfalls
Walk along a muddy track for about an hour and you’ll eventually make it to the Marinka Waterfalls. If you’re feeling lazy, you can just pay a motorbike to take you for about 10’000 COP.
Entry is 10’000 COP at the time of this writing and gives you access to a jungle garden and two pretty big waterfalls. The first one is the biggest, and you’ll feel its fine spray from a hundred metres away. This waterfall is the most majestic.
The second waterfall is the best one for swimming in! Just bear in mind that it can get quite busy in the plunge pool.
There are a lot of big hammock seats in the Marinka waterfall gardens – you’ll definitely want to get a cool picture in one!
There’s also a restaurant on site that serves up delicious food for a good price!






The more majestic of the Marinka Waterfalls




Oído del Mundo
If you’re walking to Marinka Waterfalls, you’ll pass Oído del Mundo. These are a smaller and supposedly less impressive set of waterfalls that precede Marinka, but they’re much less crowded, and there’s often no one there!
Visiting Oído del Mundo is one of the best things to do in Minca, Colombia, if you really want to swim and enjoy the tranquillity of nature around you.
I’m a bit of a sucker for swimming in river water; it’s always way too cold for me. The funny thing is, I didn’t find the water to be that cold here. Owing to the smaller size of the waterfall, you can swim right up to it and sit right under the crashing water. Yes, it may be a bit of a throttling experience, but coming out of it makes you feel refreshed and rejuvenated!
Of all the waterfalls in Minca, Colombia, Oído del Mundo is my favourite!Trending11 Things I Wish I knew Before Hiking Acatenango Volcano
You might also enjoy: Visiting Tayrona National Park in Colombia: The Ultimate Guide

Play board games at Casa Loma
There are a few hostels in Minca that are well-known for offering visitors incredible experiences. Casa Loma is one of those, and the best bit is, it’s a short trek from the village centre.
Once you’ve managed to hike up the mountainside to get there (15 minutes max!), you’ll be rewarded with mountain and sea views reaching all the way out to Santa Marta and the Caribbean coast. You can’t find a better spot to watch the sunset from this close to the village!
They also have a big selection of different board games in the main outdoor common area that anyone can play. The common area layout means it’s also very easy to meet other travellers.
I’m also a massive fan of their vegan and vegetarian food. Everything on the menu tastes incredible, and for a bit of a gringo hostel, the prices are super economical. If you’re looking for a chilled evening, a visit to Casa Loma must be on any list of things to do in Minca, Colombia.






Casa Loma’s common area




Try unicycling
About two-thirds of the way up to Casa Loma, you’ll pass a circus master’s house. He offers aerial acrobatics, slackline and unicycle classes that you can try out for a fraction of the price as in other countries.
If you’re wondering what to do in Minca, Colombia, that isn’t hiking or waterfalls, this might be for you.





Go on a coffee and cacao tour
The mountains around Santa Marta are some of the best in the country when it comes to producing coffee and cacao. A trip to Minca is therefore a perfect excuse to learn more about the harvesting and production process of both of these brown beans.
There are a few places you can do a tour. Finca La Candelaria and Finca San Rafael both do coffee and cacao tours. You can combine them or just do one. If you just want a coffee tour, you can also visit La Victoria.
For my cacao tour, I visited Finca San Rafael. I could not have been more impressed. Included in the tour, I was given a cacao face mask to smoother all over my face, paired with the most delicious cup of cold hot chocolate I’ve ever had. There are only two places I’ve ever tried hot chocolate and liked it; Finca San Rafael and Oaxaca, Mexico. 
Going on a coffee or cacao tour is one of the best things to do in Minca, Colombia. But whatever finca you decide to go to, they’re all very out of the way. You either have to walk for a few hours to get there or pay for a motorbike to take you.

























Lounge in a giant hammock at Sierra Minca
Remember I mentioned earlier about some of the best hostels in Minca? Well, this is another one of them. Maybe even the best. There are a few places in and around Minca that allow you to sit in their suspended hammocks, but none are quite as big as the ones they have at Sierra Minca.
For a small entrance fee, you can enjoy the phenomenal mountain and sea views from their gigantic hammocks and spend a whole morning here. The only downside is that Sierra Minca is quite a long motorbike ride out of Minca. That’s code for expensive. But if you’re wondering what to do in Minca to chill, this might just be it.

Drink cocktails at the Lazy Cat
Wondering what to do in Minca, Colombia, at night? Go and grab a cocktail!
You’ll find The Lazy Cat on Minca’s main street. It’s the ideal spot to end your day of adventuring by splashing out on a few ridiculously cheap cocktails. Colombians are so friendly that you’ll also more than likely end your night here with a couple of new friends.






Making friends with a new four-legged pal




Visit Pozo Azul waterfall
The truth is, the area around Minca is blessed with an abundance of waterfalls.
Pozo Azul is a 2-hour walk from the centre of Minca and you can either walk it, or pay for a motorbike to take you.
Here you can go for a swim in the VERY cold river water and enjoy the waterfall from afar. There’s a risk of getting pulled under the closer you get to the falls, so unfortunately you can’t swim past the rope barrier. Regardless of that, it’s a fun place to cool off, splash about and spend a few hours.






Pozo Azul Waterfall




Hike to a viewpoint
When you ask most people about going on hikes in Minca, they’ll surely tell you about the Los Pinos viewpoint hike. It’s one of the lengthier hikes in Minca, taking about 4 hours to get there from the village.
But the views are more than worth it! If you’re very lucky, you may run into a motorbike on the way down that’ll take you back for a fee. If not, it’s another 3 hours walk down to the village.
But now for the best hike in Minca; the 360º viewpoint hike. Not only is this one much more unheard of, but it’s also a lot closer. It only takes 2 hours to get there (although it is steep!), and you’ll probably have the place to yourself! If you’re looking for hikes in Minca, don’t skip this one!
As the name suggests, the views from up here are unparalleled. Who says no to a 360º view of mountains, sea and luscious forest?! Hike up in the afternoon so you can watch the sunset for an extra special experience. For those wondering what to do in Minca, Colombia, with an abundance of energy, this is for you!
Use this guide to help you get there.

Stop for ice cream in Waira
On the way back from your Marinka waterfall hike, you’ll pass by Waira, a chic ice cream and coffee shop. I had the best ice cream I’ve had in all of Colombia here!
They have some very funky ice cream flavours, from intense chocolate made with organic cacao to dragon blood and even lavender sorbet! The cakes they have up on display will also make your mouth drool. It’s best to come here on an empty stomach.






Our huge portions of cacao and dragon’s blood ice cream




Go to the cinema
Yep, you read that right. Minca has its very own cinema. Ask in La Miga bakery for more information on what movies are being shown and the times.
The only downside is they normally only show them in Spanish, so it’s not ideal for everyone.

Go birdwatching
Colombia is the most biodiverse country in the world per square kilometre. Knowing that, it’s unsurprising that it’s also the second most biodiverse country in the world when it comes to birds.
Minca is one of the best places to go birdwatching in the country. Even if you’re not the biggest bird enthusiast (I’m not!), going on a bird-watching tour with Jungle Joe will bring the bird passionista out of you!
If you can muster the courage to wake up in time for the 6 am start, Joe will fill you in with all sorts of incredible bird and wildlife facts and point out some very cool and funky birds you otherwise never would have noticed. I’m talking hummingbirds, toucans and macaws!
Despite having to roll out of my bed at 5 am, this was one of my favourite activities in Minca, Colombia. And for only 50’000 COP per person, it’s a steal!






















Jungle Joe’s bird watching tour




Go on a motorcycle ride
There are a lot of hikes in Minca, which equates to a lot of walking. You might like to treat yourself to a motorbike ride and then walk back from somewhere to make things easier.
Plus, motorbike rides in and of themselves are one of the most fun things to do in Minca, Colombia! The tracks in the area are often bumpy and sea-saw-like in terms of their ascents and descents, so whizzing around the muddy mountain paths on a motorbike can be quite a thrilling experience!
Just beware that it’s not common for you to be given a helmet unless you ask for a rider that’s willing to lend you theirs.
You might also enjoy: A Backpacker’s Guide to Palomino, Colombia









Treat yourself to a chocolate massage
Okay, this is definitely not one of the most budget-friendly things to do in Minca, but your tired backpack-carrying back will thank you for it later.
Casa Loma offers a selection of different massages in their very peaceful open-air jungle massage room. If I recall correctly, they offered energy, wood, hot stone, and chocolate massages, all for about 120’000 COP.
Since Minca is a big cacao-producing region, I opted for the one-hour chocolate massage for 120’000 COP. It’s the only massage I’ve ever had, and I’m coming back for more!
If you’re wondering what to do in Minca, Colombia, to really really relax and unwind, this is it!






Casa Loma’s relaxing jungle massage room




Where to eat in Minca
Over the last few years, Minca has grown to have quite a number of restaurants, cafes and bakeries popping up all over the village centre. A lot of them are also vegan and vegetarian-friendly.
Although you might not be able to try them all, I visited 80% of them for you. Here are my favourites…
Casa Aney 
This is without a doubt my favourite place to eat in Minca. The place is run by an Israeli and serves up really yummy pizza and lots of different Middle Eastern dips like hummus, babbaganoush and tzatziki. They also sell homemade kombucha (ask for a behind-the-scenes tour of where it’s made!) and a mouth-wateringly delicious seaweed salad.
In the evening, lots of candles come out turning it into the most romantic date spot in the village!
Make sure you visit Casa Aney as one of your things to do in Minca, Colombia. I visited on my last night so I only had the chance to GO there once. I was so gutted that I couldn’t visit again.
If you’re wondering what to do in Minca, Colombia, at night, go and eat in Casa Aney!






Some of the best food I had in Colombia




Duni
At the foot of the hike to Casa Loma (just off the village’s park), you’ll see Duni tucked away in a corner. This is another vegan-friendly place that serves up scrumptious breakfasts and has some really yummy baked treats. I recommend the brownie and the cheese and spinach rolls.

Casa Loma
I mentioned this place before, but it deserves mentioning again. Casa Loma’s restaurant serves up a whole array of different foods from burgers, to lasagna, salad bowls and delicious desserts. The best bit is, it’s all plant-based, and every single dish is a treat to your taste buds (and your wallet!).






A wholesome start to the day at Casa Loma




Marhaba
This is another place serving up middle eastern flavours and falafel plates. You can also indulge in one of their tasty pizzas on one of their wooden stools overlooking the street. This is a great little spot, but if you want hummus, Casa Aney does it better.
If you were wondering where to eat in Minca, hopefully, this list has helped a bit!

Where to stay in Minca
CASA LOMA – If you’re looking for a hostel that’s not too far from the village but still has an in-the-middle-of-nowhere feel to it, Casa Loma is your best bet. Just a 15-minute hike up from Minca village, it boasts panoramic views over a thriving green mountain landscape and as far out as the city of Santa Marta. The wooden hilltop house also has lots of common areas with swing chairs and board games, plus they have live music on the weekends and daily yoga classes. This is definitely one of my go-to hostels in Minca.






Sunset views from Casa Loma




SIERRA MINCA – Hostel views don’t get much better than the ones at Sierra Minca. It’s home to the largest hammocks in the world and a pool with unrivalled views over the mountains. But for all of these benefits, you do have to sacrifice your proximity to Minca village. Because of this, you’re very reliant on the services they provide. Motorbike taxis take about 30 minutes to get to the hostel, which will set you back at least 20’000 COP for each journey. Visiting Sierra Minca is one of the top things to do in Minca, Colombia, though. So if you don’t stay here, you can still visit for a day!
FINCA CARPE DIEM – If you’re interested in staying in an eco-lodge while in Minca, this is my top pick. While it’s not actually in Minca (it’s in the nearby village area of Paso del Mango), this is a very recommendable place to stay if you want to be surrounded by rivers, mountains and forests. Come here for wild, untamed nature and a few days of being disconnected (or more connected you could say).
LA GUACAMAYA – While I wouldn’t say this is one of the best hostels in Minca, it’s definitely one of the cheapest. The dorm room is super basic, but you only pay 20’000 COP per night, and it’s right in the centre of Minca village. They also have a pet macaw here!






Hostel La Guacamaya’s friendly macaw




What to do in Minca, Colombia: a summary
Anddddd…that’s a wrap. Hopefully, this guide on what to do in Minca, Colombia, will help you plan your trip to this wonderful mountain village. With so many fun things to do in Minca, Colombia, you might end up extending your stay here just like me.

Visiting Minca, Colombia



FoodTravelDrink



Apr 6

Written By 






On my recent trip to Colombia with my sister, we spent a couple nights in Minca, which is in the mountains a few hours north of Cartagena. It’s a small town with plenty to do!Scroll down to see a map of all mentioned places.EatDuni























Duni is a cafe serving a full breakfast and lunch menu, as well as homemade breads and ice cream, in a beautiful space. Get here early for your pick of their homemade breads, and definitely enjoy a meal if you have time. Everything was fresh, delicious, and thoughtfully presented. If you’re feeling decadent, go for their chocolate bread french toast. The staff is lean and service can be a little slow, so it’s definitely a place to sit and relax. La Miga













Another cafe with delicious breads and coffees. The chocolate bread at La Miga, which is very different from Duni’s version, was so good. We saw some people ordering sandwiches, but breads and coffee seem to be their main thing. When we were there, they were offering generous samples at the counter. On Google Maps this is called “Crumb Bakery.”Sailor Will























Sailor Will was on our way to our hostel, so we stopped in for lunch right after we got off the colectivo from Santa Marta. The space was beautiful, the staff was really friendly, and we could see the small kitchen from our table. We shared the menu del dia, which was a big portion of rice, meat, plantains, avocado, and beans. We didn't get pictures of the food, but obviously plenty of pictures of the Club Colombias we washed our meal down with.El Bistro de la Victoria























El Bistro de la Victoria is the restaurant attached to Finca Victoria (more on that below). After a very steep hike up to the coffee farm, we were so happy to sit down at the Bistro with a couple of cold beers and sandwiches before our coffee tour. The sandwiches were huge and we probably could have shared one. Nevada Cerveceria























The beers we drank at El Bistro de la Victoria are from Nevada Cerveceria, the brewery right next door to the coffee farm. You can only find their beers in a few places in this region, so I recommend trying them if you come across them. We had the pilsner and really liked it, and if you’re judging a book by its cover, the labels are pretty cool. Casa Loma

 









 

Casa Loma, the hostel we stayed at served homemade vegetarian breakfast, lunch, and dinner at reasonable prices. We ate dinner there both nights of our stay, and some people who weren’t even staying at the hostel came for the meal (it’s about a 10-minute hike uphill from town, which should say something!). Each night there’s one appetizer, entree, and dessert on the menu, which is posted on a chalkboard that morning so you can decide if you want to sign up. The food is individually plated and served at the shared tables where you can get to know your fellow travelers. Both our dinners were delicious with generous portions and high-quality ingredients. Lazy CatWe didn’t get to try Lazy Cat, right across from Sailor Inn, but we heard from multiple people that while eating on the outdoor deck, a Toucan stopped by, ate some fries, and flew away. Sounds worth it just for that!DoSunset























The sunsets in Minca are beautiful. Get up to any high point and watch the sun go down and the sky change colors in between the mountains. We watched the sunset from the sunset deck at our hostel both nights. Like the dinners, many people come up to Casa Loma just for that. Pozo Azul























It’s about a 45-minute hike up the road from town before a 15-minute walk down the path to Pozo Azul, a swimming hole. The first swimming hole was packed. We crossed this area (you have to walk through the water, so we had to take our socks and sneakers off and then put them back on) and hiked up to the second swimming hole, which was less crowded and a bit deeper. We watched teenage boys jump off the high cliff before we jumped off a slightly lower cliff :). We hiked just a little bit farther up to another swimming hole that was virtually empty, where we sat and read for a bit. There are no amenities here, save for a couple ladies grilling plantains at the entrance, so come prepared. Finca Victoria























We debated hiking up to Finca Victoria from Pozo Azul or taking a moto-taxi but ultimately walked up and took a moto-taxi back down. This hike up is very steep and challenging, but with beautiful views. We speed-walked (as much as we could uphill) and it took us 50 minutes from the start of the path to Pozo Azul. We started with lunch at the restaurant attached to the farm (see above) before our tour. There’s no tour schedule, they just take you around whenever you’re ready, maybe waiting to see if a couple more people show up. The tour costs $15,000 pesos and includes a cup of their coffee. La Victoria has been around since 1892 and uses water and gravity to power their automatic production of coffee beans. It’s pretty impressive and we learned a lot from our knowledgeable tour guide.Chill























Especially if you’re coming to Minca from a big city, this is a good time to relax. Life seems pretty laid-back here, and our hostel was a great place to catch up on reading, play cards, and take in the views while surrounded by nature.Moto-taxiAs mentioned, we took a moto-taxi back to our hostel from Finca Victoria. Look for the guys in black polos with blue writing; these are the official Minca moto-taxi drivers. It’s a fun experience, just hold on tight!  We were only in Minca for two nights so didn’t get to do everything. Here are a few other activities we read about on the blog Practical Wanderlust: Las PiedrasLas Cascadas de MarinkaFinca La CandelariaShoppingStayCasa Loma Minca























We were really happy with our decision to stay at Casa Loma. As I mentioned a couple times above, people who aren’t even sleeping there come up for meals and the sunset because they have so much to offer. They have a number of different types of accommodations including private rooms, open-air huts, dorms, hammocks, and tents. We chose the Casa Luna hut for its views and its private bathroom (the only one offered). This hut is secluded from the rest of the camp and has a wide open view of the mountains, plus the night sky full of stars - something you don’t get in New York City! The shower has the same view, which was pretty amazing. The hut has a mosquito net over the bed and a big wooden locker, which we put all our stuff in when not using, including toiletries, for security and to keep animals away. The hut has a curtain in lieu of a door, and the noises we heard in the night took some getting used to, but waking up and going to bed with that view was worth it. Even though we stayed in the secluded hut with our own bathroom, we took advantage of the benefits of staying in a hostel, such as group dinners and meeting other travelers. We enjoyed sitting in the hammocks and at the picnic tables in the main lodge playing cards and reading. If you can manage the hike up to Casa Loma from town, I recommend booking a room here!EAT AND DO IN MINCA - MAP VIEW

The Complete Travel Guide To Minca, Colombia

By Isabel Leong
4 May 2022
 No Comments




Home » Colombia » The Complete Travel Guide To Minca, Colombia



Minca, the gateway to the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, is a magical and mystical town located in the mountains of Colombia’s Caribbean coast.
The name Minca comes from the Tayrona Indians who inhabited the area prior to the Spanish conquest. It’s said that they were peaceful people who lived in harmony with nature. Minca is a great place to learn about Colombian culture and history. There are a variety of museums and cultural centres in town, so be sure to visit some of them during your stay.
The village is surrounded by lush rainforest and is home to many waterfalls, rivers, and hiking trails.
If you want to escape the heat and humidity of Colombia’s coastal cities, Minca is the perfect place to relax and enjoy the cooler temperatures of the mountains. The fresh air and stunning views of the Sierra Nevada will quickly make you forget the hustle and bustle of city life.

Things to Do in Minca, Colombia
Top attractions in Minca
Colombia’s Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta is the world’s highest coastal mountain range and provides ample opportunity for outdoor adventure. There are many things to do in Minca, including hiking, swimming, bird watching, and exploring the numerous waterfalls and rivers in the area.
Hiking
There are many hiking trails in Minca Colombia, ranging from easy to complex. The most popular trail is the one to the Los Pinos, which takes about 2.5 to 3 hours to complete. The hike starts at the Minca River and follows a steep path through the forest until you reach the top of the mountain. The views from the top are breathtaking and well worth the effort it takes to get there.
If you’re looking for a more challenging hike, you can try the trail to El Cerro Kennedy, which is the highest point in the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. This Colombia hiking trail is not for the faint of heart, as it includes a steep climb to the summit. However, the views from the top are more than worth the effort.
It takes about 4-5 hours to complete and offers panoramic views of the mountains and coastline. Its isolation from the nearest towns makes it perfect for stargazing at night. 
Waterfalls








The Marinka Waterfall (location) is the most popular and is located just a short walk from the town centre. The waterfall is only about 2 metres high, but the pool at the base is perfect for a refreshing swim. The thick forest surrounding the waterfall creates a cool and refreshing atmosphere, making it the perfect place to escape the heat of the day.
Another popular waterfall is Pozo Azul (location), which is located near the village of Fundación. This waterfall is known for its clear blue waters and is a great place to take a swim.
Cascada Perdida (location) is another waterfall that’s worth visiting. This hidden gem is located off the beaten path and requires a bit of hiking to get to, but it’s well worth the effort.
There are also several smaller waterfalls located throughout Minca, many of which can be reached by hiking one of the many trails in the area.
Viewpoints
Minca is home to some of the best views in all of Colombia. Mirador de la tagua la y (location) is one of the most popular viewpoints and offers a panoramic view of the Sierra Nevada. This viewpoint is located just a short drive from Minca and is the perfect place to watch the sunset.
Another popular viewpoint is Mirador de Los Pájaros (location), which offers stunning views of the valley below. This viewpoint is located just a 15-minute’ walk from Minca and is the perfect place to watch the sunrise or sunset.
There are also many other great viewpoints located throughout Minca, so be sure to explore the area and find your own favourite spot.
Coffee Plantations








Minca is home to some of the best coffee plantations in all of Colombia. 
Finca la Victoria (location) is one of the most popular plantations and offers a tour of the facilities as well as a chance to sample some of the delicious coffee. It’s the oldest and most traditional coffee plantation in Minca, established in the late 19th century. Finca la Victoria is located just a short drive from Minca and is the perfect place to learn about the coffee-making process.
La Candelaria Coffee Farm B&B is another popular plantation that offers a tour of the facilities as well as a chance to sample some of the delicious coffee. La Candelaria is located just a few minutes’ walk from Minca and is the perfect place to stay if you want to learn about the coffee-making process.
There are many other coffee plantations in Minca, each with its own unique history and offerings. Be sure to check out a few of them during your stay.
What To Eat In Minca, Colombia
We loved getting our breakfast here!
Minca is known for its fresh produce and coffee. There are plenty of fruit and vegetable stalls around town where you can buy locally grown produce. Make sure to try some of the exotic fruits, such as lulo and zapote.
If you’re looking for something heartier, there are plenty of restaurants serving traditional Colombian food. Try the arepas, which are corn cakes usually filled with cheese or meat. Another popular dish is bandeja paisa – a plate of rice, beans, meat and plantains.
And, of course, you can’t come to Minca without trying the coffee. The coffee here is some of the best in Colombia, so make sure to visit a café and try a cup for yourself. The restaurants in town usually have their own coffee plantations, so you can also take a tour and learn about the coffee-making process.

Caficosta
When it comes to Minca, it’s not complete without coffee. The coffee in Caficosta is a product of more than 2,600 hard-working farmers from the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, Serranía del Perijá and San Lucas. I enjoyed taking a respite here in the midst of rainy Minca amongst the modern interior.

Where To Stay in Minca, Colombia

There are many accommodation options available in Minca, ranging from hotels to hostels. The luxury hotels in Minca offer stunning views and top-notch service. If you’re looking for a more affordable option, there are many good hostels located in the town centre.
No matter what your budget is, you’re sure to find a place to stay that suits your needs. Minca is a great place to relax and enjoy the beauty of Colombia. Here are some of our favourite hotels and hostels in Minca.

Trekker Glamping
Trekker Glamping is a luxury camping experience that’s perfect for those who want to enjoy the great outdoors without sacrificing comfort. This hotel offers a variety of amenities, such as private bathrooms, a swimming pool, and a restaurant. The American breakfast offered each morning is a real treat.
The garden inside the hotel is absolutely beautiful, and the staff is very friendly and helpful. If you’re looking for a luxurious stay in Minca, Trekker Glamping is the perfect option.

This hotel offers a variety of amenities, including an infinity pool, a spa, and a restaurant. The rooms are all beautifully decorated and offer stunning views of the surrounding area. This 3-star hotel is the perfect place to enjoy a luxurious vacation.
Minca Ecohabs

They also have a tour deck overlooking the valley. The hotel has a restaurant that serves organic and locally grown food. Minca Ecohabs is the perfect place to stay if you want to experience the beauty of nature and learn about sustainable living.

Hotel Brisas de Minca
This hotel is a great option for those who want to be in the heart of nature. It’s located in the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, which is one of the most biodiverse places on earth. Just 200 m from the Minca river, this is the perfect place to stay if you want to be close to all the action. The rooms are comfortable and clean, and the staff is friendly and helpful.
The garden and swimming pool are also great places to relax and take in the beautiful surroundings. There is also a shared lounge area where you can meet other guests and make new friends. The hotel is just 45 minutes away from the airport, so it’s easy to get to.
Hotel Minca – La Casona
If you want to stay in a colonial-style hotel that overlooks the stunning landscape of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, then Hotel Minca – La Casona is the place for you. This hotel is located in the town of Minca, which is nestled in the foothills of the Sierra Nevada.
The Hotel Minca – La Casona offers a variety of rooms and suites, all of which are decorated in a traditional Colombian style. The hotel also has an on-site restaurant that serves traditional Colombian cuisine.
The Pozo Azul waterfall is just 1 km away from the hotel, and the El Dorado bird reserve is 2 km away.
Budget-Friendly Hotels in Minca, Colombia
Casas Viejas by Masaya
If you want to get away from it all, this is the place for you. With only nice rooms, this hotel is perfect for those who want peace and quiet. The hotel is located just 30 minutes from the city centre but feels like a world away.
The ensuite bathrooms are spacious and have all the amenities you need, including a hairdryer and free toiletries. The rooms also have a TV, air conditioning, and Wi-Fi. This hotel has an outdoor pool, a sun terrace, and a garden. There is also a bar where you can get drinks and snacks.
Siembra Boutique Hostel – Minca
This hostel is located in the mountains of Minca and is a great place to stay if you want to be close to nature. The rooms are simple but comfortable and have private bathrooms.
The hostel has a restaurant, bar, and lounge area where you can relax and meet other travellers. There is also a swimming pool and a sun terrace. An American breakfast is served each morning and there is also a restaurant inside.
Minca is a great place to stay while exploring the Santa Marta area. With so many things to do and see, you’re sure to find something that interests you. Whether you’re looking for a beach vacation or an adventure in the jungle, Minca is the perfect place to visit.
Weather In Minca, Colombia

Minca is surrounded by the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, a coastal mountain range that runs along the Colombian coast. It affects the local climate, making the weather in Minca fairly mild all year round. However, there are still some seasonal variations to be aware of. 
The rainy season runs from May to November, and during this time the town can be quite wet. The average temperature during the rainy season is 22ºC/ 72ºF. 
From December to April, it’s the dry season. The weather’s a bit cooler during this time, with an average temperature of 28ºC/ 82ºF daytime and 18ºC/ 64ºF at night.
Overall, the weather in Minca is pleasant and temperate, making it a great place to visit at any time of year.
Best Time To Visit Minca, Colombia
If you’re planning a trip to Minca, the best time to go is during the dry season. However, if you don’t mind a little rain, you can still enjoy all that the town has to offer during the wetter months. Just be sure to pack your raincoat.
January to March is the high season in Minca, so expect higher prices and larger crowds. The weather is also quite nice during this time.
If you’re looking to avoid the crowds and save some money, April to June is the low season. The weather is still pleasant during this time, although it can be a bit cooler, with average temperatures of 22ºC/ 72ºF daytime and 12ºC/ 54ºF at night.
January is the month of festivals in Minca, so if you’re looking to experience the local culture, this is the time to go. However, keep in mind that accommodation and tour prices will be higher than usual. August is also a popular month to visit, as this is when the Minca Coffee Festival takes place.
Overall, Minca is a great place to visit any time of year. However, if you’re looking for the best combination of weather and value, April to June is the best time to go.
How To Get To Minca, Colombia 
Parking prices for car, moto, bicycle
Santa Marta is accessible by plane, bus, and boat from most major cities in Colombia.
If you’re coming from Bogotá, the capital of Colombia, you can take a direct flight to the Simon Bolivar International Airport in Santa Marta. The flight takes about 1 hour and 30 minutes.
Alternatively, you can take a bus from Bogotá to Santa Marta. The journey takes about 18 hours.
From Cartagena, you can take a direct flight from the Rafael Núñez International Airport to Santa Marta. The flight takes about 2 hours and 40 minutes. 
You can also take a bus from Cartagena, but the journey is much longer, taking about 4 hours.
How To Get From Santa Marta To Minca, Colombia
Minca is located in the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta mountains, less than an hour’s drive from the city of Santa Marta. Once you’re in Santa Marta, there are a few different ways to get to Minca.
By car/ motorcycle
The best way to get there is by car or motorcycle. A taxi from Santa Marta to Minca will cost around COP 37,000/ USD 10 and will take around 35 minutes.
If you’re driving, the best way to get to Minca is by taking the coastal road from Santa Marta. The journey takes about 45 minutes.
By bus
You can also take a bus from Santa Marta to Minca, but the journey is much longer. The buses are comfortable but can be crowded, so it’s best to get on early. The journey takes more than 1 hour and costs around COP 11,000/ USD 3. The Cootrasminca bus service operates several times a day from 7 am to 6 pm. The bus to Minca doesn’t depart from the main bus station; instead, it leaves from the bus stop behind the central market. 
Minca is a great place to go motorcycling. With its winding roads and stunning scenery, it’s no wonder this town is such a popular destination for motorcyclists. So, grab your helmet and hit the open road!
How To Get Around Minca, Colombia
Minca is surrounded by mountains, with one main road cutting through it and a smaller road making a loop. The best way to get around is by car or motorcycle. You can also rent a motorcycle taxi (“moto-taxi”), which is a popular form of transportation in Minca. You can also take a mule or a jeep, but it’s not appropriate if you want to go up and down the mountains.
Most of the town centre is accessible by foot, and there are plenty of places to explore, including waterfalls, coffee plantations, and hiking trails.
If you want to explore further afield, you can take a private tour. These tours typically last for about 6 hours and will take you to places like the Los Naranjos waterfall and the Pozo Azul natural pool.

The access to waterfalls, lakes, and rivers makes Minca a great place for swimming, so don’t forget to bring your bathing suit!

Sunscreen is also a good idea if you’ll be spending time in the water, as the sun’s rays can be reflected off of the water.
It’s also a good idea to bring insect repellent, as there are mosquitoes in Minca. Be sure to use a repellent that contains DEET for the best protection. 
If you’re planning on swimming in one of the many waterfalls or pools in Minca, you’ll need to bring a bathing suit.

What To Wear in Minca, Colombia

However, if you’re planning on going hiking or swimming, be sure to wear appropriate clothing and footwear. Hiking boots or sneakers are a good idea, as the trails can be slippery.
If you’re swimming, you’ll need a bathing suit. It’s also a good idea to bring a light jacket or sweater, as the temperature can drop in the evening. 
Nightlife in Minca, Colombia

 There are plenty of things to do during the day, however. You can go hiking, swimming, bird watching, or explore the many coffee plantations in the area. You can also visit one of the many waterfalls or pools in Minca.
Money

Most places in Minca only accept cash, so be sure to have enough on hand to cover your expenses.
There are a few places that accept credit cards, but they usually charge a fee.
Tipping is not common in Minca, but it’s always appreciated if you receive good service.

Secondly, Minca is located in a remote area, so it’s important to be prepared for anything.

WHY YOU NEED TO VISIT MINCA, COLOMBIA



ColombiaSouth America



14 May

Written By Faria
















Visiting Minca? Check out my list of 10+ fun things to do whilst you're there. And yep... There's hiking involved!Famous for its chocolate and coffee farms, the sparsely populated town of Minca lays nestled in the hills and mountains of Colombia's Sierra Nevada. Recently growing in popularity with backpackers and travellers, it's the perfect place to escape the hustle and bustle of Santa Marta and indulge into the luscious green hills surrounding the town.With an array of hiking trails at your feet, hiking in Minca will take you to some incredible viewpoints. Get out those trekking toes because you're about to experience some incredible landscapes in Colombia. It would be great to take you with me on an adventure around Minca, but for now, I'll have to resort to listing out amazing things to do in Minca on your next visit to Colombia! Everything you need to visit Minca, Colombia













Gorgeous sunsets in MincaDive into Cascada de MarinkaAround a 2 hour walk from the main town of Minca, head to the Cascada de Marinka for a refreshing dip into the waterfalls. With natural pools of fresh water, it's perfect for swimming or lying in one of the many hammocks at the foot of the hill. There's an entrance fee of $5,000 COP and a restaurant by the waterfall.Handy tip: Download maps.meon your phone before your hikes in Minca. It's pretty easy to take the wrong route and then have to backtrack.













Cascada de MarinkaIndulge in coffee and chocolate farmsA trip to Colombia wouldn't be complete without a visit to a local Finca. There are many coffee farms scattered around Minca offering daily tours and a chance to buy locally produced coffee directly from producers.La Candelaria also includes daily chocolate tours where they take you through the production of cacao into chocolate. I loved this tour so much, I'm thinking of writing a blog post on it at a later date! As it involved chocolate, this was easily one of my favourite tours! My recommendation? Come in the afternoon with a friend and ask the tour guide to taste the cacao bean when it's sweet. It's strange having something sweet for it to then taste really bitter at the end of the process. You'll even get to finish the tour with a chocolate face mask!The price of a chocolate or coffee tour is $25,000 COP. 










La Candalaria





Getting down and dirty...La Victoria, a coffee plantation farm what also produces beer also has daily tours starting at around $15,000 COP. It's around a 2-hour walk from the main town or 20 minutes on a motorbike.Hike to a 365 degree panoramic viewIf you do anything in Minca, do this!! My advice? Head there for sunset and bring a torch!To get to the panoramic views, head to hostel Mundo Nuevo. From Mundo Nuevo hike up the hill around 10 minutes more until you get to a sign that points to Mirador 360. Keep heading up the hill and there's a clear sign at the end for Finca Alesia. Turn left. You'll see some houses on the right and a sign on a tree that points you towards Mirador 360.You'll be walking along a narrow path for around 10-15 minutes. Lookout for a small sign on the left pointing you in the direction of a very narrow trail.Follow the trail to the top for stunning views and a breathtaking sunset.If you're unsure, ask the staff inside Mundo Nuevo. The cats are really friendly! 













Mirador 360 - honestly my photos don't do it justice!Take a moment at Los PinosLos Pinos is a beautiful viewpoint over the valley and Santa Marta. It's best to go on a clear day as the clouds can obscure the visibility.From Minca it's around 3-4 hours walking and on a hot day it can be pretty exhausting. A good idea is to take a motorbike there and hike back.Chill out in a hammock and do nothingYep. This is totally a thing. Especially in Minca where they're reputed to have more hammocks than people.Casa Elementor is a favourite but there are better ones IMO, especially ones where you don't need to pay for a view of the mountains. Hostels Mundo Nuevo, Casa Viejas and Loma Nueva all have stunning views. 










Hammock Minca | Sunset | Colombia





My favourite hammock! Underneath a mandarin tree overlooking the mountains in MincaBird watchingThere are over 300 species of birds in the Sierra Nevada, the highest diversity of birds on the planet, in Minca you have the opportunity to see 162 species. It's an early morning tour with Jungle Joe and one of the highest rated activities to do.Hike up to Loma NuevaIn fact, the hike up to Loma Nueva is totally worth it. It's cooler and fresher and you can even have a drink on their terrace as you soak up the wonderful mountain air.










Hammock Loma Nueva Hostal





More hammocks!Dine at Casa Loma for dinnerThe hostel Casa Loma nestled in the hills has beautiful views and a delicious vegetarian meal every evening at around 8 - 8:30 pm. All ingredients are fresh and due to limited space, you'll need to get there early to register unless you're already staying in the hostel.Hike in a loop around MincaLimited for time? If you're feeling adventurous, the entire loop around Minca can be done in 9-10 hours. Either clockwise or counter-clockwise you'll head past Cascada de Marinka, the waterfall Pozo Azul and Los Pinos.










Minca Colombia





Stunning luscious green mountains!Watch the sunset from Mundo NuevoMy recommendation would be to stay at Mundo Nuevo. Fullstop.When I popped by for directions to mirador 360, the serene calm atmosphere and beautiful views prompted me to stay in Minca for 3 more nights!Every evenings, everyone gathers at the bottom of the ledge to watch the sun go down on Minca as the sky lights up in dusty hues of pink and amber.It's definitely one of my top five places I've stayed in South America!













Mundo NuevoHead to Donde Raul for Friday night SalsaLooking for a place to let loose for an evening? Donde Rahl is a popular place where locals and tourists gather to salsa and dance the night.If you're like me and can't dance, don't worry! There's always someone around to help you out and even teach you a step or two!Where to eat in MincaFor one reason or another, most recommendations included going to the Lazy Cat, apparently one of the best places in town.Whilst I ate there a couple of times and it was all lovely, I didn't find it to be anything special. But maybe that's just me.Casa de Loma is high up there on my recommendations and Duni is absolutely amazing.If you're looking for something simple, the French bakery, La Miga, in town that does some delicious home made baguettes with various dips of hummus. 










Minca Sunsets





Yep! Another gorgeous sunset!How to get to MincaOutside Mercado Publico in Santa Marta, there are regular buses/jeeps that leave for Minca for $8000 COP. Stock up on insect repellentDuring the dry season the mosquito situation wasn't too bad. However, if you are planning on hiking in the mountains, definitely bring insect repellent.The best kind is locally sourced. Casa de Graciela located on the main road, with a sign for selling honey outside, two houses down from the butchers sells the best insect repellent around for $7000 COP. And it's natural! It did the trick and I barely got bitten!Just ask a few locals, they'll point you in the right direction if you tell them you're looking to buy 'repellente' at 'Casa de Graciela'. You can even show them this picture.










Natural Insect Repellent





It's natural!How to get aroundMost people hike to get to places. However, it can get really hot and there are motor taxis you can take to pretty much anywhere. The drivers are next to the 'bus stop' in town. Prices are fixed and vary depending on where you go.Where to stayHostel Coco Bomgo is located in the centre of town which is really convenient if you're looking to enjoy the restaurants and local hang outs. Incredibly clean and friendly, they were a great place to spend my first few nights. Check here for availability.My biggest recommendation is to spend a couple of nights in the mountains, enjoying delicious food, sunsets and beautiful views. Mundo Nuevo was so amazing that I ended up extending my stay in Minca. Their outdoor bathrooms are pretty cool and the hammock underneath the mandarin tree is the perfect place to chill as you watch the sunset over the mountains. With great wifi, check out the latest prices here.Casas Viejas, also located in the mountains is also another perfect chill out hostel and gets booked out pretty quickly. Check it outhere.It's also worth pointing out that unless you have a light enough backpack, you'll be taking a motorbike taxi to the hostels located in the mountains. It's around $20,000-25,000 COP.Planning a trip or fancy a freebie? Unauthorized use is prohibited.TravelTravelerSip Your Way Through Colombia’s Coffee TownsA new coffee destination bears fruit in the country’s north.ByBill FinkPhotographs byFrancesco LastrucciPublished July 19, 2016• 8 min readShareTweetEmailSomething is brewing in the small Colombian town of Minca. It smells of caramel, bark, charcoal, and chocolate. The source? Coffee beans, fresh from backyard roasters, their sharp burnt odor cutting through the humid tropical haze.Here in northern Colombia, the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta range rises straight from the shores of the Caribbean. Long left undeveloped due to political troubles, this now peaceful area draws urban Colombians and savvy international visitors to the palm-fringed beaches of Tayrona National Park, the ancient archaeological site of Ciudad Perdida, and the birding paradise of the jungles around Minca.Recently, Minca and the Sierra Nevada have begun to attract coffee-loving travelers, a collection of connoisseurs and curious backpackers eager to discover what Juan Pablo Campos, general manager of the Lohas Beans trade group, calls “the most important Colombian region for organic coffee.”Using a pestle, Minca coffee grower Angel Maria Orozco peels the hard outer skin of dried coffee beans.Photograph by Francesco LastrucciPlease be respectful of copyright. Unauthorized use is prohibited.While coffee is not native to Colombia, the plant has flourished for centuries on the country’s steep, shade-covered mountains, with rainfall, altitude, and temperatures ideal for growing the mellow, medium-bodied arabica-style bean. Colombia has been exporting coffee since the early 1800s, and in 2015 alone shipped 840,000 tons of coffee beans. Represented by the fictional ambassadors Juan Valdez and his trusty burro, Conchita, “Café de Colombia” has become known worldwide.A map of northern Colombia, where the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta range rises straight from the shores of the Caribbean
NG Maps, World Database on Protected AreasPlease be respectful of copyright. Unauthorized use is prohibited.Colombia’s better-known “coffee triangle” in the country’s southwest now supports a well-trod tourist track between luxury lodges and standardized plantation tours, but the Sierra Nevada still offers an authentic journey into the past—and a taste of the future of Colombian coffee. In remote highlands, indigenous tribes of Kogi and Arhuaco lead the way in organic coffee production, developing a sustainable farming network that combines traditional spiritual beliefs with modern planting knowledge. These farms embrace generations-old techniques and tools to produce sought-after organic blends, with many beans “triple certified” as organic, fair trade, and rain forest-friendly.A local harvest of organically grown coffee fruit eventually ends up as a drink to linger over at Ikaro Café, in Santa Marta.Photograph by Francesco LastrucciPlease be respectful of copyright. Unauthorized use is prohibited.The gateway to the region is the sunny Caribbean seaside city of Santa Marta, where the bitter street blend of tinto (from the Spanish word for ink) black coffee is sweetened with spoonfuls of sugar. Coffee aficionados will skip the tinto, as well as the ubiquitous Juan Valdez chain stores, and head to Santa Marta’s smaller shops, such as Ikaro Café.Exploring the area’s coffee culture is best done during harvest season, from about November through February, and can be as simple as hiring a taxi for the approximately 40-minute, 15-mile bumpy ride from the sea to the hills. Visits to tribal lands require special permission or an organized trip from an approved local operator such as Wiwa Tour.A stop at Hacienda la Victoria above Minca is like traveling to 1892, when the farm was founded. Husband-and-wife owners Micky and Claudia Weber provide a bean-to-brew education on growing, processing, and roasting coffee. Visitors will see the same well-oiled machinery in use since the farm’s beginnings: water-powered generators, gravity-driven sorters, and hand-cranked presses. Tours conclude with a tasting of their blends, often accompanied by homemade apple pie. Other local farms promote scheduled and drop-in tours and tastings of high-end coffees—a difference from only a few years ago when Colombia had an unofficial policy of “export the best, and drink the rest.”At Hacienda la Victoria, owner Claudia Weber inhales the robust aroma of freshly washed and dried coffee beans.Photograph by Francesco LastrucciPlease be respectful of copyright. Jan 12 The Finca at Minca

Lisa Phillips 
Colombia, South America











One near-death experience on a motorbike and I had arrived in Minca. A spectacular hideaway tucked up high in the Sierra Nevada mountains overlooking the Colombian coast. After a high energy three weeks of excess, Minca was a welcome and very necessary change of pace. Queue instant nature immersion: big sunsets that drop over the mountain range and coastline, abundant bird life (over 350 varieties that will captivate your attention) and my favourite - coffee fincas (farms).The lure of fresh brew was strong. So strong that we opted to stay at a third generation local coffee finca - La Candelaria. For over 100 years this delightful family has been growing and producing organic coffee. Operations have expanded to grow cacao plus 15 fruit plants and a resident rescue toucan, Touky. We're BFFs. Take a private coffee and cacao tour, enjoy home cooked meals and have an outdoor shower overlooking the coast (seriously, it's boobs out for the birds) - sublime! DO:Hangout with La Candelaria's rescue Toucan, Toucky.Take a coffee and cacao tourPut on an organic cacao face mask (licking off optional)Firm up the butts and thighs trekking around the Sierra Nevada mountain rangeEAT & DRINK:Food made by the family with love, and coffee from seed to cup at La CandelariaThe Lazy Cat in Minca town serves up wholesome food that is not fried!
