results.content: Skip to content    Search   Close     Icon-instagram-1      Icon-facebook      Pinterest      Icon-linkedin           Home Blog Free eBook About Us Content Marketing Services    X   Icon-instagram-1      Icon-facebook      Pinterest      Icon-linkedin     Search   Close   Home Blog Free eBook About Us Content Marketing Services    XThings To Do in Minca, Colombia – Sustainable Travel GuideThings To Do in Minca, Colombia – Sustainable Travel Guide       By:  Conor Armor	                       Photo by: Niels Van AltenaNestled in the lush mountains of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, Minca is a magical village that has captured the hearts of visitors from around the globe. A paradise for eco-tourists and nature lovers, Minca offers a unique blend of natural wonders, vibrant culture, and an immediate sense of relief from the wet, oppressive heat of Santa Marta!Often referred to as “Colombia’s hidden gem,” Minca is an idyllic retreat from the hustle and bustle of city life, and a gateway to exploring the breathtaking beauty of Colombia’s northern coast. As you wander through its misty forests and cool, flowing rivers, you’ll find yourself falling in love with the picturesque landscapes and unforgettable encounters with the local wildlife.A Brief History of MincaFounded in the early 19th century, Minca began as a small coffee and cacao farming community. The fertile soils and mild climate of the Sierra Nevada made it the perfect location for cultivating these precious crops. Over the years, Minca has evolved from a sleepy village to a thriving eco-tourism destination, attracting visitors seeking an off-the-beaten-path adventure.Despite its growth, Minca has managed to maintain its authentic charm and rich cultural heritage. The village still prides itself on its agricultural roots, with coffee plantations and organic farms scattered throughout the mountainside.Minca’s Strategic LocationMinca’s unique appeal lies in its strategic location within the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, a UNESCO-listed biosphere reserve and the world’s highest coastal mountain range. This exceptional setting provides diverse landscapes and ecosystems to explore, ranging from lush rainforests and cloud forests to pristine beaches and sparkling waterfalls.The Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta is also home to several indigenous communities, including the Kogi, Arhuaco, Wiwa, and Kankuamo tribes. Their presence adds a layer of cultural richness and history to the region and offers visitors the chance to learn about and engage with these ancient peoples and their traditions.Getting TherePhoto by: David HertleWhile Minca may feel like a world away from the busy city of Santa Marta, reaching this serene village is surprisingly accessible. Located just 45 minutes away, Minca offers several transportation options to fit the needs of every traveler.By car or taxi: Private cars and taxis can be easily arranged from Santa Marta or other nearby cities, offering a comfortable and convenient way to reach Minca. Be sure to negotiate the fare before starting your journey.By public transport: For a more budget-friendly option, catch a “colectivo” (shared minibus) from the Santa Marta market. These minibusses depart regularly throughout the day, providing an affordable and authentic local travel experience.Regardless of your chosen mode of transport, the journey to Minca promises stunning views of the verdant mountains and sparkling coastline, setting the scene for the adventures that await you.Best Time to Visit MincaThanks to its tropical location and high elevation, Minca enjoys pleasant temperatures throughout the year, making it an ideal destination at any time. However, to make the most of your visit, consider the following factors when planning your trip:Rainy season: Minca’s rainy season typically occurs between May to November, with October and November being the wettest months. While the rain can create lush, vibrant landscapes, it can also make some trails and activities less accessible. If you don’t mind the occasional shower, traveling during the rainy season can offer a more immersive experience in nature.Dry season: The dry season, which runs from December to April, is considered the best time to visit Minca. With lower chances of rain, you’ll be able to explore the great outdoors with ease and fully appreciate the breathtaking beauty of the region.Events: If you’re interested in experiencing local culture and traditions, plan your visit around one of Minca’s events. We recommend you join one of the events at the cultural center Sonidoselva, a place where community members can exchange their expertise and knowledge to preserve and share the vibrance of Minca.Sustainable Tourism in MincaNatural Wonders of MincaPozo AzulThis stunning waterfall nestled deep within the jungle, is a favorite among locals and visitors alike. The crystal-clear waters create inviting pools, perfect for a refreshing swim amidst the vibrant foliage. Surrounded by nature’s symphony, Pozo Azul offers a serene escape from the bustling village.Marinka FallsMarinka Falls, another gem in Minca’s collection of waterfalls, provides a picturesque backdrop for a rejuvenating dip or an impromptu picnic. With easy access from the village, Marinka Falls is a must-visit destination for anyone seeking a moment of solitude and connection with nature.Enchanting Jungle Treks and TrailsThe lush jungles surrounding Minca beckon to be explored, offering countless trails that lead to awe-inspiring vistas and hidden oases. Embark on a guided trek with a knowledgeable local or follow well-trodden paths to uncover the secrets of the rainforest. Along the way, you’ll encounter vibrant flora and fauna, ancient trees, and captivating views that will leave you breathless.Sustainable Eco-Lodges and AccommodationsIn recent years, Minca has experienced a surge in eco-friendly accommodations, catering to the growing demand for sustainable tourism. Most stores and accommodations are still locally owned or owned by expats who’ve started small businesses in Minca and stay true to the village’s laid-back, unpolished spirit.That said, overdevelopment tends to encroach on even the most hidden destinations. That’s why it remains important that while visiting Minca, you support local businesses that contribute positively to Minca’s sustainable growth and help to maintain its unique character. Below, you can find a quick list of recommendations.Where To Stay In Minca, ColombiaThese eco-lodges demonstrate their commitment to preserving the environment through various sustainable practices, such as solar power, rainwater harvesting, and organic waste management. They also engage with local communities to foster a mutually beneficial relationship that respects the environment and cultural heritage.As a guest at one of these lodgings, you have the opportunity to learn about and participate in various cultural and environmental projects, deepening your connection to the place and its people.Finca Carpe Diem: This tranquil ecolodge, situated near the famous Pozo Azul waterfall, features comfortable cabins, a natural swimming pool, and easy access to hiking trails and nature excursions.Casa Loma Minca: Perched on a hillside overlooking the village, Casa Loma Minca offers stunning views, cozy accommodations, and a range of activities, including yoga classes and birdwatching tours.Mundo Nuevo Eco Lodge: Located in the heart of the Sierra Nevada mountains, Mundo Nuevo is an off-grid ecolodge that offers a true escape into nature. With a focus on sustainability, permaculture, and community, this retreat is perfect for travelers seeking an immersive and transformative experience.Minca Ecohabs: Nestled amidst lush greenery, Minca Ecohabs offers a luxurious eco-friendly experience with beautifully designed private cabins, an on-site spa, and spectacular views of the surrounding landscape.What To Do In Minca, ColombiaHiking and Mountain BikingPhoto by: Berend LeupenThe rugged terrain and lush forests surrounding Minca provide the perfect setting for exhilarating outdoor adventures. Explore the region’s extensive network of trails on foot or by bike, taking in the spectacular scenery, fresh mountain air, and diverse flora and fauna along the way. Hike to the top of Los Pinos, or simply join the guests at Casa Loma, to take in one of Minca’s famous sunsets.Zip-lining and Canopy ToursExperience the thrill of exploring Minca from above! Glide along the zip line at Hostal Sierra Minca, and enjoy panoramic views from the viewing platforms. Canopy tours with Vivamos Colombia not only offer an unforgettable adventure but also provide a unique perspective on the region’s diverse ecosystems.Birdwatching in a Birding ParadiseMinca is a birdwatcher’s paradise, boasting a diverse array of bird species that call the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta home. With over 350 species to spot, including some found only in this region, you’ll be captivated by the vibrant colors and melodic calls that fill the air.Join a birdwatching tour with Jungle Joe to maximize your chances of spotting elusive species, such as the Santa Marta parakeet or the endemic white-tailed starfrontlet. Regardless of your level of birdwatching experience, Minca offers a unique opportunity to connect with nature and deepen your appreciation for its winged wonders.Photo by Rodrigo FloresGuided Coffee ToursColombia is definitely one of the best countries for coffee lovers! As eco-tourism continues to flourish in Minca, many coffee farms have adopted sustainable practices to minimize their impact on the environment and promote a harmonious relationship with nature. Immerse yourself in the fascinating world of coffee cultivation by embarking on a guided tour. Go on a coffee tour or chocolate tour at Finca La Candelaria.As you stroll through the verdant plantations, you’ll learn about the intricate process of coffee production, from planting and harvesting to roasting and brewing. The insights and stories shared on these tours not only deepen your appreciation for your morning brew but also foster a connection with the people and landscapes of Minca.Kogi Indigenous CommunityA visit to Minca is not complete without immersing yourself in the rich cultural tapestry woven by its indigenous communities. Sol de Minca is an eco-lodge founded in collaboration with the Kogi people, who call the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta home. The place welcomes travelers from around the world, invites them to reconnect with nature, and teaches them, with the help of the Kogi community, the vital concept of reciprocity towards the earth.Culinary DelightsDon’t miss the chance to sample some of the region’s most iconic dishes, such as “sancocho” (a hearty stew), “arepas” (cornmeal patties), and “patacones” (fried plantains). For a true farm-to-table experience, visit one of Minca’s organic farms or eco-lodges, where you can savor the freshest ingredients and flavors the region has to offer.Engage with the LocalsIf you’re keen to mix it up with a more local crowd, play a game of pool at Billares Central.Extending Your Trip: Nearby DestinationsTayrona National Natural ParkA must-visit destination for nature lovers, Tayrona National Natural Park is located just a couple of hours from Minca. Boasting pristine beaches, lush tropical forests, and abundant wildlife, this protected area offers a diverse range of outdoor activities, including hiking, birdwatching, snorkeling, and simply soaking up the sun on one of its many picturesque beaches.The Lost City (Ciudad Perdida)For the more adventurous traveler, embarking on a trek to the Lost City (Ciudad Perdida) is a truly unforgettable experience. This ancient archaeological site, hidden deep within the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta mountains, can only be accessed via a challenging multi-day hike. Those who undertake this journey will be rewarded with the chance to explore the fascinating ruins of an ancient civilization that predates Machu Picchu by several centuries.PalominoLocated along Colombia’s Caribbean coast, the laid-back village of Palomino offers a peaceful retreat for those seeking sun, sand, and tranquility. With its uncrowded beaches, warm turquoise waters, and relaxed atmosphere, Palomino is the perfect place to unwind and enjoy a slower pace of life.Santa MartaAs the jumping-off point for many travelers visiting Minca, Santa Marta deserves some exploration in its own right. This vibrant coastal city boasts a rich history, dating back to its founding as South America’s oldest Spanish settlement in 1525. Spend time wandering its historic center, visiting museums, dining on delicious seafood, or simply enjoying the lively atmosphere of its bustling streets.La GajiraHome to the indigenous Wayuu people, La Guajira offers an opportunity to learn about and engage with their unique traditions, while supporting the local community. Venture through the mesmerizing Cabo de la Vela and the stunning sand dunes of Punta Gallinas.Tips for Responsible and Conscious Travel in MincaBe Mindful of Your Water and Energy UsageWater and energy resources are precious commodities in many parts of Colombia, including Minca. Be mindful of your consumption by conserving water, turning off lights and appliances when not in use, and minimizing your reliance on single-use plastics.Learn Some Basic Spanish PhrasesWhile English is spoken by many in Minca’s tourist industry, making an effort to learn and use some basic Spanish phrases can go a long way in fostering positive connections with locals. Simple phrases like “hola” (hello), “gracias” (thank you), and “por favor” (please) can help break down language barriers and create a sense of mutual respect.Support Local BusinessesBy choosing to spend your money at locally owned businesses, you contribute to the local economy and help support Minca’s residents. This can include dining at family-run restaurants, purchasing from artisan markets, or booking accommodations and activities with locally owned establishments.Mision Gaia an NGO based in Minca that leads projects spanning from animal health and well-being, responsible tourism, and sustainable development. You can read more about their work and contribute a donation if you would like, through their website.Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs)1. Is Minca Safe for Tourists?Yes, Minca is generally considered a safe destination for tourists. However, it’s always a good idea to exercise caution and follow standard travel safety guidelines, such as keeping an eye on your belongings, being aware of your surroundings, and avoiding poorly lit or isolated areas at night.2. What is the Local Currency, and What Payment Methods are Accepted?The local currency in Minca is the Colombian peso (COP). While some establishments in the village accept credit cards, it’s a good idea to carry enough cash for your expenses, as ATMs can be scarce. Make sure to exchange your money in Santa Marta before arriving in Minca, as currency exchange services may be limited.3. What is the Primary Language Spoken in Minca?The primary language spoken in Minca is Spanish. However, many people working in the tourism industry speak English, so communication should not be a significant barrier for most visitors. Learning some basic Spanish phrases can greatly enhance your experience and help build rapport with locals.4. What Should I Bring for my Trip to Minca?It’s essential to pack items that will help you stay comfortable and prepared for the diverse activities and experiences the region has to offer:Lightweight, breathable clothing is ideal for warm days and cooler evenings.A waterproof jacket or poncho will come in handy for unexpected rain showers.Sturdy, comfortable hiking shoes are a must for exploring the area’s trails.Sun protection, such as sunscreen, sunglasses, and a hat, will help shield you from the intense tropical sun.Insect repellent is crucial to ward off mosquitoes and other insects.A reusable water bottle will keep you hydrated during your adventures and reduce plastic waste.5. Can I Find Reliable Internet Connectivity in Minca?Internet connectivity in Minca can be limited, with some areas offering only patchy or slow connections. While many hotels and cafes provide Wi-Fi, it’s essential to manage your expectations when it comes to internet speeds and availability. Embrace the opportunity to disconnect and immerse yourself in the natural beauty and rich culture of this enchanting destination.       Conor Armor  PrevPreviousThe Ultimate Guide to Whale Watching in 2023 Next22 Top Things to do in Lisbon, Portugal: A Sustainable Travel GuideNext   /  Where To Go   Join the Hidden Lemur Mailing List   Sign UpSHARE THIS                    Things To Do in Minca, Colombia – Sustainable Travel Guide       By:  Conor Armor	   Photo by: Niels Van AltenaNestled in the lush mountains of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, Minca is a magical village that has captured the hearts of visitors from around the globe. With easy access from the village, Marinka Falls is a must-visit destination for anyone seeking a moment of solitude and connection with nature.Enchanting Jungle Treks and TrailsThe lush jungles surrounding Minca beckon to be explored, offering countless trails that lead to awe-inspiring vistas and hidden oases. Embark on a guided trek with a knowledgeable local or follow well-trodden paths to uncover the secrets of the rainforest. Along the way, you’ll encounter vibrant flora and fauna, ancient trees, and captivating views that will leave you breathless.Sustainable Eco-Lodges and AccommodationsIn recent years, Minca has experienced a surge in eco-friendly accommodations, catering to the growing demand for sustainable tourism. Most stores and accommodations are still locally owned or owned by expats who’ve started small businesses in Minca and stay true to the village’s laid-back, unpolished spirit.That said, overdevelopment tends to encroach on even the most hidden destinations. That’s why it remains important that while visiting Minca, you support local businesses that contribute positively to Minca’s sustainable growth and help to maintain its unique character. Below, you can find a quick list of recommendations.Where To Stay In Minca, ColombiaThese eco-lodges demonstrate their commitment to preserving the environment through various sustainable practices, such as solar power, rainwater harvesting, and organic waste management. Explore the region’s extensive network of trails on foot or by bike, taking in the spectacular scenery, fresh mountain air, and diverse flora and fauna along the way. Hike to the top of Los Pinos, or simply join the guests at Casa Loma, to take in one of Minca’s famous sunsets.Zip-lining and Canopy ToursExperience the thrill of exploring Minca from above! Glide along the zip line at Hostal Sierra Minca, and enjoy panoramic views from the viewing platforms. Canopy tours with Vivamos Colombia not only offer an unforgettable adventure but also provide a unique perspective on the region’s diverse ecosystems.Birdwatching in a Birding ParadiseMinca is a birdwatcher’s paradise, boasting a diverse array of bird species that call the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta home. With over 350 species to spot, including some found only in this region, you’ll be captivated by the vibrant colors and melodic calls that fill the air.Join a birdwatching tour with Jungle Joe to maximize your chances of spotting elusive species, such as the Santa Marta parakeet or the endemic white-tailed starfrontlet. Regardless of your level of birdwatching experience, Minca offers a unique opportunity to connect with nature and deepen your appreciation for its winged wonders.Photo by Rodrigo FloresGuided Coffee ToursColombia is definitely one of the best countries for coffee lovers! As eco-tourism continues to flourish in Minca, many coffee farms have adopted sustainable practices to minimize their impact on the environment and promote a harmonious relationship with nature. Immerse yourself in the fascinating world of coffee cultivation by embarking on a guided tour. The place welcomes travelers from around the world, invites them to reconnect with nature, and teaches them, with the help of the Kogi community, the vital concept of reciprocity towards the earth.Culinary DelightsDon’t miss the chance to sample some of the region’s most iconic dishes, such as “sancocho” (a hearty stew), “arepas” (cornmeal patties), and “patacones” (fried plantains). This ancient archaeological site, hidden deep within the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta mountains, can only be accessed via a challenging multi-day hike. Those who undertake this journey will be rewarded with the chance to explore the fascinating ruins of an ancient civilization that predates Machu Picchu by several centuries.PalominoLocated along Colombia’s Caribbean coast, the laid-back village of Palomino offers a peaceful retreat for those seeking sun, sand, and tranquility. About Carpe Diem
Finca Carpe Diem Ecolodge is a hidden gem for hiking and relaxation lovers in Paso del Mango, near Minca. We offer three swimming pools, magnificent views over endless forests and river access from the house. There are lots of hikes you can make (short and long, guided or on your own). We also provide yoga classes, massages and farm-to-table meals.
Our facilities are set up in the midst of lush forests with lots of open and green spaces between rooms and communal areas.  We don’ t have close neighbours, there are no bars or restaurants nearby (except ours 🙂 and traffic is very low.  Wherever you go or walk, you will feel the fresh air around you. This remote situation can be inspiring and makes it relatively easier for us to comply with COVID-19 procedures and precautions (see also our section Corona).
Geographically we are located in the Minca area (North Colombia) but our exact location is the village of Paso del Mango (READ DIRECTIONS CAREFULLY), a beautiful tropical valley crossed by two rivers. The landscape is the same but less people and more wild nature compared to busy Minca.
What do we offer more specifically?
– The lodge is located right within our farm and nature reserve. You will be surrounded by mountains, rivers and forests on every side.
– Three swimming pools with large terraces, and spectacular views over the surrounding mountains and jungle.
– Located alongside a crystalline river with private entrances, dozens of swimming holes and impressive waterfalls nearby (some are over 40 meters high).
– Unique excursions within short walking distance to coffee and cacao farms, lost cities, nature reserves, private 360° viewpoints, waterfalls and birding places.
– All rooms come with air conditioning or natural rooftop materials so you have a good rest at all times.
– All beds have first quality mattresses. Most private rooms are provided with King size mattresses and cotton bed linen.
– A lounge with comfortable seats, and huts with lots of hammocks to relax.
– Unique restaurant with family styled healthy “farm-to-table” dinners. We also offer meat, chicken and fish a la carta. Our breakfast comes with homemade bread. We do NOT have a kitchen for the guests to use, only a fridge where you can keep some of your things.
– We are committed to social and environmental goals. For example, we are undertaking a tree planting project. Also, all our staff lives in the village nearby and we work with locally manufactured ingredients, often from our own farm.
– Important: you will be on a Colombian finca. There is loooots of space and nature on all sides. You will find a peaceful, relaxing and comfortable environment that is hard to find elsewhere.
Check in at room is at 2PM. Check out is at 10 AM.
We accept credit cards for which we charge 6 %.
